unnormalised: **Energy & Utilities: Solar Rooftop Subsidies Boost Adoption in Rajasthan**
normalised: **Energy and Utilities: Solar Rooftop Subsidies Boost Adoption in Rajasthan**

unnormalised: Jaipur, Rajasthan – The Rajasthan Renewable Energy Corporation Limited (RRECL) announced revised and expanded subsidies for residential solar rooftop installations, effective immediately. The move aims to accelerate the adoption of clean energy across the state and reduce reliance on conventional power sources, particularly during peak summer months.
normalised: Jaipur, Rajasthan – The R R E C L announced revised and expanded subsidies for residential solar rooftop installations, effective immediately. The move aims to accelerate the adoption of clean energy across the state and reduce reliance on conventional power sources, particularly during peak summer months.

unnormalised: Under the new scheme, individual households can avail subsidies of up to 40% for rooftop solar systems up to 3 kW. For systems between 3 kW and 10 kW, a subsidy of 20% will be applicable. Dr. Meena Sharma, Director of RRECL, stated that the updated subsidies are expected to significantly reduce the initial investment costs for homeowners.
normalised: Under the new scheme, individual households can avail subsidies of up to forty percent for rooftop solar systems up to three kilowatt. For systems between three kilowatt and ten kilowatt, a subsidy of twenty percent will be applicable. Doctor Meena Sharma, Director of R R E C L, stated that the updated subsidies are expected to significantly reduce the initial investment costs for homeowners.

unnormalised: "We anticipate a surge in applications following this announcement," Dr. Sharma commented. "This initiative directly supports the 'Atmanirbhar Bharat' vision by promoting indigenous solar manufacturing and empowering citizens to generate their own electricity." The subsidy extends to systems covering up to 1000 sq ft. A typical 3 kW system can save homeowners approximately Rs. 30,000 annually on their electricity bills. The program also includes provisions for net metering, allowing consumers to sell excess power back to the grid. Similar initiatives are being considered in Gujarat and Maharashtra, paving the way for wider adoption of rooftop solar across India.
